required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Multispectral Fluorescence as a Tool to Separate Healthy and Disease Related Lymphatic Anatomies in Prostate Cancer.
clinical_study.official_title: MultiSPectral fLuorescence Imaging as a Tool to Separate Healthy and Disease Related Lymphatic Anatomies During Lymph Node Dissections in Prostate Cancer.

brief_summary.textblock: Multispectral imaging of the lymphatic draining pattern of the tumor and the abdominall wall/lower limb to evaluate technical feasibility to differentiate these patterns and in the future reduce the amount of complications that result from damage to lymphatic structures.

detailed_description.textblock: By preventing unnecessary resection of healthy lymphatic tissue during extended lymph node dissections, we will be able to reduce the degree and amount of complications that result from damage to the lymphatic structures. We aim to evaluate the technical feasibility of imaging two different lymphatic drainage profiles, namely that of healthy tissue (i.e. the lower limbs/abdominal wall) and that of the primary tumour (i.e. prostate). To realize the differentiation, real-time multispectral fluorescence imaging of two spectrally different tracers (the lymphangiographic tracer fluorescein (injected in the lower limbs and abdominal wall) and sentinel node (SN) specific tracer Indocyanine Green (ICG)-99mTc-nanocolloid (injected in the tumour, followed by ac control lymphoscintigraphy and SPECT/CT)) will allow for multispectral (or multicolor) fluorescence. Complementary to the routine surgical procedure, e.g. radical prostatectomy with extended pelvic lymph node dissection (ePLND), the lymphatic drainage pattern of both the tumour and of healthy tissue, i.e. lower limbs and abdominal wall, will be determined in the surgical field/surgical specimens.

primary_outcome.measure: Feasibility of this intraoperative visualisation technique
primary_outcome.description: The ability to visually differentiate the draining lymphatics of the lower limbs and abdominal wall, (LNLower limb/abdominal wall; fluorescein) from the disease associated LNs (LNprostate cancer; ICG-99mTc-nanocolloid) during lymph node dissection

secondary_outcome.description: Determine the anatomical relationship between lymphatic tumour spread and the lymphatic drainage profiles of the lower limbs and primary tumour (i.e. prostate) in relation to ePLND template.

intervention.description: Sentinel node biopsy with Indocyanine Green -Technetium - Nanocolloid + fluorescein

study_pop.textblock: Men >18 yrs with primary diagnosed prostate cancer eligible for robot assisted radical prostatectomy and lymph node dissection

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Male, aged â‰¥ 18 years.
- WHO performance status 0,1, or 2.
- Written informed consent.
- Histopathologically confirmed adenocarcinoma of the prostate
- Increased risk of nodal metastases according to the MSKCC nomogram (> 7%)
- Scheduled for surgical (laparoscopic) prostatectomy including ePLND-
- Suitable for RP and ePLND, as per institutional guidelines
Exclusion Criteria:
- Prostate cancer patients with prior abdominal or inguinal surgery
- History of allergy to iodine, food or medicinal induced urticaria, asthma, eczema, or aller-gic rhinitis
- Hyperthyroid or thyroidal adenoma
- Kidney insufficiency
- History of oversensitivity to FLUORESCITE composites
- Patients using beta-blockers

overall_official.last_name: Henk van der Poel, Prof. MD
